Primary Objectives:

  • Find User Flag

  • Find Root Flag

Procedure:

We will start with NMAP to determine open ports on the machine IP. Let’s use the -v flag to get some more information from our scan.

nmap -v [machine_ip]

SSH is open on port 22 and HTTP on port 80. Additionally, we are given a host name here which we will need to add to /etc/hosts.

Note: Without the [machine_ip] lookup.thm entry in hosts, we will get the following.

NMAP previously showed us that a web server on port 80 is open, let’s check one more thing before opening it up in a browser.

If we telnet into the HTTP port using telnet [machine_ip] 80 we get a successful connection.

We are going to use an HTTP GET to grab what is found at the root location with the following command GET / HTTP/1.1. Notice how the terminal accepted the line and is now idle again? Let’s follow up the first command by specifying our host host: lookup.thm followed by hitting enter two more times.

Success! We get a response back with some information. Let’s take a quick look and see if anything is of particular interest. In this case, the only thing that really pops out to me is login.php but for the purposes of this room we are going to move on and look at the page in a browser.

The loaded page is a simple login screen asking for a username and password.
